    Marginal Structural Survival Models

    Robin Evans

    2024-07-12

    MSMs.Rmd

    Marginal Structural Models

    In this vignette we consider marginal structural models for time-to-event data. Begin by loading the library.

    library(survivl)
options(digits=4)

    Then we define our formulas and family variables. We will have one baseline variable, and a single time-varying covariate, treatment and outcome. More specifically, let: \[\begin{align*} W &\sim \operatorname{Gamma}(1/2, \, 2) \\ Z_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t-1}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim N(0.7 Z_{t-1} + 0.2 X_t, \, 1)\\ X_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim \operatorname{Bernoulli}(\operatorname{expit}(0.5 X_t + 0.25 Z_{t-1}))\\ P(Y_t = 1 \mid do(\overline{X}_{t}), W) &= \exp\{ - X_t + W/10\}, \end{align*}\] and assume that there is a Gaussian pair-copula linking \(Y_t\) with \(Z_{t-1},Z_t\), which also depends upon \(W\). We assume that the parameter for the \(Y_t\)-\(Z_{t-1}\) interaction is 0.2, and that for \(Y_t\)-\(Z_{t}\) given \(Z_{t-1}\) is 0.3.

    forms <- list(W ~ 1,
              Z ~ Z_l1 + X_l1,
              X ~ X_l1 + Z_l0,
              Y ~ W + X_l0,
              list(Y = list(Z ~ W)))
fams <- list(3, 1, 5, 3, c(1))
pars <- list(W = list(beta=0, phi=1/2),
             Z = list(beta=c(0,0.7,0.2), phi=1),
             X = list(beta=c(-0.5,0.25,0.5)), 
             Y = list(beta=c(1,-1/10,1/5), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y=list(Z=list(beta=c(0.5, 0.0))))
)
link <- list("log", "identity", "logit", "inverse")

    We can now simulate \(n=10^5\) observations from the model over 10 time points.

    n <- 1e5
set.seed(124)
dat <- msm_samp(n, T = 10, formulas = forms, family = fams, pars = pars, link=link) 
                # method = "rejection")
datl <- surv_to_long(dat, lag=1)

    Checking the fit

    We can check that our simulation has the correct parametric distributions. We use a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to check the distribution of \(W\), and then regressions to test the distributions of the \(Z\)s and \(X\)s.

    ks.test(dat$W, "pgamma", scale=1/2, shape=2)
    ## 
##  Asymptotic one-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
## 
## data:  dat$W
## D = 0.0032, p-value = 0.3
## alternative hypothesis: two-sided
    summary(glm(Z ~ W + Z_l1 + X_l1, data=datl))$coefficients
    ##              Estimate Std. Error  t value   Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -0.003757   0.007639  -0.4918  6.228e-01
## W           -0.002179   0.005153  -0.4229  6.724e-01
## Z_l1         0.702495   0.003785 185.6214  0.000e+00
## X_l1         0.198876   0.008608  23.1034 1.384e-117
    summary(glm(X ~ W + X_l1 + Z, data=datl, family=binomial))$coefficients
    ##               Estimate Std. Error   z value   Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept) -0.4911393   0.016312 -30.10820 3.784e-199
## W           -0.0003152   0.010943  -0.02881  9.770e-01
## X_l1         0.2422572   0.017882  13.54788  8.155e-42
## Z            0.4916998   0.007465  65.87003  0.000e+00

    Indeed, each of these variables is consistent with the parameters we used. For the survival outcome, we can use inverse probability weighting. The survey package can account for the additional uncertainty introduced by weighting.

    library(survey)

    Now we estimate the propensity scores, and fit the IPW model.

    ps <- predict(glm(X ~ W + X_l1 + Z, data=datl, family=binomial), type = "response")
wt <- datl$X/ps + (1-datl$X)/(1-ps)
summary(svyglm(I(1-Y) ~ W + X, family=binomial(log), start=c(-2,1/10,-1/5), 
               design=svydesign(~1, data=datl, weights=wt)))$coefficients
    ## Warning in eval(family$initialize): non-integer #successes in a binomial glm!
    ## Warning: step size truncated due to divergence
    ##             Estimate Std. Error t value  Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -1.01108   0.010266  -98.49 0.000e+00
## W            0.09779   0.006154   15.89 9.634e-57
## X           -0.18834   0.011382  -16.55 2.296e-61

    Multiple time-varying covariates

    We may well be interested in simulating more than one time-varying covariate. We can easily allow for this, first by simply specifying another formula in the second element of our list…

    forms2 <- forms
forms2[[2]] <- list(Z1 ~ Z1_l1 + Z2_l1 + X_l1, 
                    Z2 ~ Z2_l1 + X_l1 + Z1_l0)
forms2[[3]] <- X ~ W + Z1_l0 + Z2_l0
fams2 <- fams
fams2[[2]] <- c(1,1)
pars2 <- pars
pars2 <- c(pars2,
           list(Z1 = list(beta=c(0,0.7,0.3,0.2), phi=1),
                Z2 = list(beta=c(0,0.5,0.2,0.1), phi=1)))
pars2$X <- list(beta = c(0,0.25,0.1,0.3))
link[[2]] <- rep("identity", 2)

    … and then by modifying the elements relating to the copula.

    forms2[[5]] <- list(Y = list(Z1 ~ W, Z2 ~ W))
fams2[[5]] <- list(c(1, 1))
pars2$cop <- list(Y=list(Z1=list(beta=c(0.5,0.2)),
                         Z2=list(beta=c(0.25,0))))

    We can then simulate as before.

    dat2 <-  msm_samp(n, T = 10, formulas = forms2, family = fams2, pars = pars2, 
                  link = link, method = "inversion")
dat2l <- surv_to_long(dat2, lag=1)

    Checking the distributions, these all seem fine.

    summary(glm(Z1 ~ W + Z1_l1 + Z2_l1 + X_l1, data=dat2l))$coef
    ##               Estimate Std. Error  t value   Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -8.593e-05   0.008344  -0.0103  9.918e-01
## W            1.300e-03   0.005538   0.2348  8.144e-01
## Z1_l1        7.070e-01   0.003678 192.2254  0.000e+00
## Z2_l1        2.991e-01   0.003980  75.1490  0.000e+00
## X_l1         2.082e-01   0.008523  24.4283 3.965e-131
    summary(glm(Z2 ~ W + Z2_l1 + X_l1 + Z1, data=dat2l))$coef
    ##               Estimate Std. Error   t value   Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -0.0008266   0.008333  -0.09919  9.210e-01
## W            0.0008448   0.005549   0.15223  8.790e-01
## Z2_l1        0.4949865   0.004181 118.39399  0.000e+00
## X_l1         0.2074983   0.008597  24.13656 4.457e-128
## Z1           0.1034376   0.003259  31.74011 3.345e-219
    summary(glm(X ~ W + X_l1 + Z1 + Z2, data=dat2l, family=binomial))$coef
    ##             Estimate Std. Error z value   Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  0.02104   0.017402  1.2088  2.267e-01
## W            0.23572   0.012022 19.6076  1.332e-85
## X_l1        -0.01234   0.017900 -0.6893  4.907e-01
## Z1           0.10434   0.006681 15.6168  5.598e-55
## Z2           0.29840   0.007970 37.4393 8.976e-307

    For the outcome, we again apply IPW, and obtain:

    ps <- predict(glm(X ~ W + X_l1 + Z1 + Z2, data=dat2l, family=binomial), type="response")
wt <- dat2l$X/ps + (1-dat2l$X)/(1-ps)
glmY <- svyglm(I(1-Y) ~ W + X, family=binomial(log), start=c(-1,1/10,-1/5), 
               design=svydesign(~1, weights=wt, data=dat2l))
    ## Warning in eval(family$initialize): non-integer #successes in a binomial glm!
    summary(glmY)$coefficients
    ##             Estimate Std. Error t value  Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -0.97576   0.011202  -87.11 0.000e+00
## W            0.09397   0.007376   12.74 3.953e-37
## X           -0.21462   0.011094  -19.34 4.148e-83
